content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple tissue sections, characteristic of a lymph node dissection from pericolic fat. I can identify at least seven distinct lymph node profiles. The nodes vary in appearance; some are densely basophilic (purple), suggesting they are reactive or partially involved by tumor, while others appear almost entirely replaced by a different, more disorganized cellular population, strongly suggesting widespread metastatic disease. The overall impression is a lymph node harvest for staging colorectal cancer, with a high suspicion for positive nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because the green box is located at the periphery of one of the larger lymph nodes (the largest one in the bottom left). This specific location is the interface between the lymph node capsule and the surrounding adipose tissue. Examining this junction is critical to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the spread of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the pericapsular fat. ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor in colorectal cancer. The irregular contour of the node at this point on low power also makes it a region of interest. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node on the slide. The zoom area is focused on one of the lymph nodes located at the bottom of the image, slightly left of center. The purpose of zooming in here is to perform a high-magnification assessment of its architecture, specifically looking at the subcapsular sinus (the area just beneath the outer capsule) and the cortex for any atypical, non-lymphoid cells that would suggest metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to systematically evaluate every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The area highlighted by the green box is one of the smaller lymph nodes located in the upper portion of the slide. This particular node appears homogenously dark and cellular at low power, which can be a sign that the normal architecture is effaced. This effacement could be due to metastatic carcinoma, so it's a critical area to examine at high magnification to make a definitive diagnosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node on the far right of the image. At this low magnification, its architecture is effaced, meaning the normal structures like follicles and sinuses are replaced by a sheet-like growth of cells. This pattern is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma, which often obliterates the normal lymph node parenchyma. A high-power view is necessary to examine the cytology of these cells to confirm or rule out metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals metastatic adenocarcinoma. There are nests and single atypical epithelial cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei infiltrating the pericapsular adipose tissue. These tumor cells are seen disrupting the normal architecture and are admixed with lymphocytes and fat cells. This finding confirms that the lymph node is positive for metastasis and, more importantly, demonstrates clear evidence of extranodal extension (ENE). The presence of ENE is a critical finding for patient staging and has significant prognostic implications.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the periphery of a lymph node. The majority of the image is filled with a dense, monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are lymphocytes. These cells form follicular structures. At the bottom, I can see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node and the adjacent adipose tissue. I do not see any large, atypical epithelial cells with irregular nuclei or glandular formation within the subcapsular sinus or the lymphoid parenchyma. My impression is that this is a reactive or normal lymph node, and in this specific field of view, there is no evidence of metastasis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see a lymph node that is almost completely replaced by a dense, monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells (lymphocytes). The normal architecture of sinuses and follicles is effaced. These cells are uniform in appearance with scant cytoplasm. I do not see any features of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glands, nests of epithelial cells, or mucin production. Therefore, this lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma. However, the pattern of effacement by small lymphocytes is highly suspicious for an incidental finding of a low-grade B-cell lymphoma, such as Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (SLL/CLL).
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the replacement of the normal lymphoid tissue by a malignant infiltrate. I see crowded, atypical cells forming poorly defined glandular and cribriform structures. The cells have enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, likely originating from a colorectal primary. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, confirming the presence of metastatic disease.
